content:
, 2012
												Risen 2 changes it main emphasis onto the pirate theme for the majority of the game & it absolutely pays off. Simply put: putting the focus on the pirating theme is excellent, as this game absolutely nails the pirates theme. From the envirionments to the actual atmosphere of the game-world and its actual inhabitants, the pirating theme here is just extremely well done + the player will get immersed into the game and its world.As always with PB's games, the level of interactivity & immersion factor is high; & NPC's run on schedules. There are choices to often make to finish quests differently, as usual. The camera is now unlocked, so moving left or right doesn't strafe. The up-side: this makes it easier to battle numerous enemies & swing directly to them. The down-side: to strafe now, you have to hold your Secondary Action key. These control changes do take some time to get used to, if you're used to Risen 1's controls. A key for rolling would've helped, since double-tapping a direction makes your character roll - which can happen accidentally. The feel of the combat itself & its controls do again feel clunky, even though this is par for the course w/ PB RPG's since Gothic 1. Even despite its few minor issues, Risen 2 is another really good RPG from PB & easy to reccommend.Grade = B

number of helpful: 0 of 2 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
er 29, 2013
												Back when I was a bit younger and started playing Video games on my own, I didnt start with games like Morrowind or Gothic, No I actually began with Risen. It was a very special game to me showing me for the first time how you could write an acceptable story into the game and still have a lot of fun in it. Risen was often seen as a Successor to Gothic and today i can for sure see why that is, back than it was one of my favorite games, it was hard, beautiful and still had an interesting gameplay. But enough of the past and lets get on with the Review. So when i heard that Risen 2 came out i wasnt that sure how it would come out, on one hand i heard that it was about pirates and included stuff like vodoo and guns, back then i was really into pirates and there werent that many games in first or third person about being a pirate (and please dont start with assassins creed, it wasnt out then i dont like it that much either) but on the other hand i was a bit conservative and werent that happy about the changes from which i heard of in the Gamemagazine called Gamestar. I bought the game anyway and the first few hours i was really interested. They set up an okay story so i was already happy but then the mess started. I had played Risen 1 a lot of times and i always was quite perficient with magic or another fighting style so i expected the character which i played (they say its the same guy) to at least be able to do stuff but no, he couldnt do anything and the reason why he couldnt remember the magic stuff was apparently because your character became a drunkard... sure. I digress, in any case i wasnt that blown away by the fighting system but i still felt okay, it suddenly changed when i arrived on the first island and i will go on with this review with as less spoilers as possible. So i arrived on the island and after going a bit into the island itself i found many things, a temple, pirates and even wildcats. I didnt have that good equipment when i came to that point but still enough to actually start to like the system, the special weapons like sand were funny and using them was maybe a bit tricky at first but you came to like it. Well, at the point when i was in the pirate town i came across some really weird and downright ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ things which made me somewhat angry. I discovered that your character wasnt a drunk no he was actually just so stupid that he didnt even know how to kick something, YES YOU HAVE TO ACTUALLY LEARN HOW TO KICK SOMEONE! But hey the story is still good right? Yes but no, the general Story might be okay, it definitely isnt a masterpiece but still good but then they throw in little things that actually straightup annoy you. At one point you enter a library in which you theoretically could find runemagic. When you do your character walks up to it and calls it old useless junk, so basically he calls that stuff which made him depending on the path in risen 1 so amazing junk. Risen 2 Dark Waters isnt a bad game, no it can definitely be fun but it also feels a bit like a teenager. They put some really stupid stuff into it and given that risen 1 wasnt the brightest of lights either i still expect though that the game is smarter than the first one. If there is a sequal i expect it to be better because if it wasnt and it couldnt show that it is really better than the original i dont see why there even is a sequal. Risen 1 wasnt a bad game and Risen 2 isnt but at some points it has just straight up flaws like, why should you use a riffle if you can throw a spear that always comes back? The combat system can become boring very fast and even if it gives many options not that many are actually helpful. The World itself is okay or even good, it is a pretty world with temples and lots of nature. The Skill and Experience system though are really bad and i would wish sometimes they were left out completely.Pro's: A pretty World, A lot of items/weapons and an acceptable range of fighting options, Pirates, an okay StoryContra's: Bad to Mediocre Experience System, Can become boring quickly, little sprinkles of really bad writingWho should buy it?: If you like Western RPG's in General and like the pirate spin-off and maybe want to pick-up a game with an acceptable story and/or maybe want to try out something new you definitely should think of picking it up but rather not at its full price.Sincerely, Lord Larker the Lurker

content:
6, 2015
												This game continues the storyline of the original Risen game.  However, they made it all Pirates of the Carribean theme, where as before, the game was dark Medieval.  I overlooked the pirate theme, but the combat system I could not.  This is an obvious console tard combat system.  Mash buttons at the right time, but even then, the animations suck and the combat is even harder and dumber than the original game, which I actually liked!  They changed too much of the game and I stopped playing after I completed the first island.  I'm not interested.  This game sucks.Edit:Riften 1 is a go anywhere you want, kill anyone you want type of game.  We call that non-linear.  They mimicked the Gothic play style where you feel out various factions, earn its trust, and annihilate the other faction and complete the story.  Even terrain exploration in Riften 1 is exemplorary because you can climb on roofs and obstacles and really get around obstacles, even if the developer didn't really intend for you to.  Risen 2 essentially locks you into a linear story and traps you on islands and you can't climb or escape the linearity.  I uninstalled it because of this very game mechanic.  I hate prison RPG's that pretend to be sandbox.  They feel like fetch quest games.

content:
y 3
												75 out of 100.It takes times (for me, 15 hours of play) to appreciate (or immerse into) this game. One of the main problems is that our hero is far from attractive, neither is his girl partner Patty. A role-playing game is a role-playing, hence if I do not feel for the main character, everything is meaningless. There are some racial issues in this game, some players may be offended.Though, after 15 hours of play I can gradually (how slow, compared to other RPGs) enjoy this game. I like the vodoo part, (you can become othere but when doing so it is not allowed to save the game, what a stupid design!) and the player really needs to "solve" quests, as there is no goal-indictator, rather than just clicking from one place to another following the auto quest-navigation system like many nowaday's RPGs. The graphic is superb, the music is good but too monotonic if you play a long time, the plot is average, the characters and actions are quite unattractive.

												My Grandfather smoked his whole life. I was about 10 years old when my mother said to him, 'If you ever want to see your grandchildren graduate, you have to stop immediately.'. Tears welled up in his eyes when he realized what exactly was at stake. He gave it up immediately. Three years later he died of lung cancer. It was really sad and destroyed me. My mother said to me- 'Don't ever smoke. Please don't put your family through what your Grandfather put us through." I agreed. At 28, I have never touched a cigarette. I must say, I feel a very slight sense of regret for never having done it, because this game gave me cancer anyway.

content:
r 28, 2015
												I didn't listen to them. I didn't listen to those reviews saying that this game is bad. I had to play this.All i can say is this: this game gave me a hell of a journey. I duelled with pirates, soldiers of the inquisition and native warriors alike. I killed more rats and giant crabs than i can count. I possessed a native and attempted to speak in his native tongue to his peers (albeit very badly). All those hours i've spent into this game, it all leads to a duel with none other than the titan lord, Mara. In the end, i was rewarded with that nice little end game music that made the hair on the back of my neck stand on end. It kinda reminds me of Kai's work somehow, from the Gothic series.Sure, the plot might be lacking, the combat system feels more like a button mashing puzzle minigame which mostly relies on timing and the game itself is glitchy, i enjoyed it despite all that. If you're like me and you like the old Gothic series i'd say go ahead and play this game. Do not heed the bad reviews and most definitely do not listen to that silly excuse of a video by AngryJoe. They cant seem to enjoy the little rpg titles like this and Gothic just because the experience is rough in the beginning, if you know what i'm saying. A few flaws wont make this game bad, in my opinion. This title deserves to stand between the 1st Risen and Risen 3, even though it lacks a bit in a few areas.I guess i'll give it an 7/10Also, you can earn glory by killing rats, so that's a 1+

												Summary: Save often if you bother trying to play this crap game.A foul, crappy sequel.Risen 1 was decent, showed promise.Decent story, wonderful graphics, well done sandboxing, modest combat. A bad quest log.Risen 2 they butchered everything.The graphics are spoiled by the over use of lens flare.The story basically takes what we know of Risen 1, and tells us it was nothing, meaningless, a dream.The sandboxing is done horribly - you're on a very crappy pair of rails, and good luck trying to move outside of them.Last and even worse, the quest system is abominable.I didn't think it was possible to make a worse quest log than Risen 1.They managed it in Risen 2.  Indefinate quests, poorly explained, no maps, no dots showing where to sortof head to.Oh, and the combat system sucks ♥♥♥♥. Humans - crappy knock off of Risen 1 combat. Everything else?  special moves and pins and other BS that you can't deal with.Lastly, open world insta-kill traps. Da fuq? Why would you put insta-kill, invisble, unseeable traps out in the open world?In risen 1, you'll find insta kill traps flagged by cracked and damaged floor, or by vents. You may not notice, but after you reload you'll see it.In risen 2, you're stuck - anytime you walk anywhere in the open world, there's risk of getting insta-killed by a trap.

content:
2016
Product received for free
												Most Disappointing Sequel Ever. Should probably avoid it unless you really want to continue the story or just happen to see it on sale.Pros:- Hilarious Dialogue - Raiding houses, beating people up and stealing their stuff is so much fun - Ranged Weapons are more viable in combat than they were in Risen 1- Murdering NPCs was removed, however enemies will stay down after being beaten, until you leave the area or left-click while they are selected- NPCs stay offended for much less time after being robbed or defeatedCons:- Despite being funny, dialogue is still super cringy for most of the game - The plot from the previous game is very poorly continued, most of it is revealed from speaking to random NPCs and making certain dialogue choices later on; but some questions still have no answers- The A.I. of both NPCs and animals is dreadful and often make clumsy decisions- Factions are even less involved than the previous game- Characters have paper-thin personalities, especially the bad guys who appear for barely 5 minutes and proceed to die in the least dramatic way possible- There are now minigames, and one of them (Shooting Contest) is near impossible and if it's needed for a quest you're going to be reloading saves for a while- Optimisation is VERY BAD. Graphics are barely a step up from Risen 1, but if you have a low-end PC and experienced near zero lag on the first game; you're still likely to get frequent game freezes on this one- Looting NPCs after beating them up is no longer possible, thus removing plenty of quest alternatives that would have been possible in Risen 1

number of helpful: 2 of 9 people (22%) found this review helpful
content:
14, 2015
												4/10This is below average. Here are some of the things I ran into with my experience with Risen 2: Sexist character writing.No, really, the first island you travel to with steelbeard as you hunt down Crow, the guard at the natives camp says something like "You sound like woman. Women talk, men act!" as he chastises you for talking too much after being accused of having hostile intentions as a pirate. He wasn't even written as a villain, just a regular passive-aggressive guard that you cannot kill or interact with beyond this. Broken Map Markers.When it came time to duel Slayne, I did not actually know where the blood square was which is where we had to duel. I checked my map, and the red objective marker simply lead me in front of the Admiral's house, when in fact Slayne was waiting for me a ways off to the side instead. This is but one of many examples where the map is flat out broken with some quests like here, and simply nonexistent with others. Another quest had required picking up multiple items, but the objective marker disappeared once you picked up just 1, so if you did not realize there were more to find in that area, and you cannot remember where it was, you wander aimlessly for a very long time, pulling your hair out. Idiotic Movement Mechanics.No, seriously, there is NO stamina bar, and rolling is by far a quicker means of on-foot travel than simple running. There was no sprint feature, even though npcs had the sprint ability which they occasionally used to catch up to my rolling being faster than their jogging. Why not just give the player that same ability!?Sloppy Level Design. Many, many, many many many times did I come across a stone staircase at a temple or tomb that did not actually connect properly with the stone floor at the end of the staircase, allowing players to see massive gaps into the game world void. This also happened a bit with terrain, such as at Garcia's Treasure hiding spot. Lazy Design.So becoming a ghost pirate is just you putting a filter over the player's screen, and changing a few detail models in the exact same environment, huh? Yeah, you disgust me Pirhanna Bytes. Also taking screenshots hard-crash the game to your desktop more than half the time based on how long you have been playing. It's unstable and sloppily coded. Vague/Stupid Quests.Certain story-required quests require the player to locate specific npcs to talk to, like normal. However, these npcs do not always show up on the map as an objective marker, and as the npc is only referred to by name, and some game areas have dozens of npcs, it's annoying to have to run around and check every single person's name just to find who you are supposed to talk to to continue the quest. Even worse, certain quest objectives themselves are just stupid. A gnome on Isle of Thieves wanted something only defined as "round and black", but there was no map marker to locate it. Again, this is a story-required quest. Round and black made me think bullet, cannon ball, bomb, lead pellet, or black pearl. Seeing as I had a black pearl on me, but no new dialogue showed up, I assumed it was something else. Little did I know, there was a hidden gnome in one of the caves that gave me a "pitch-black pearl". Each cave has only one bed, suggesting there is 1 cave per gnome, and there was already a gnome outside of this cave I had already talked to, which is why I ran all across the island for an hour and a half, checking every nook and cranny for another "round and black thing" instead of going inside. Are you serious? He didn't want a black pearl, he wanted a "pitch-black pearl" that can only be gotten from a concealed, non-map-marked npc? Yeah.... No.The list of problems do NOT stop there by any means. There are literally over a dozen other topics I could complain about and provide examples to but the review character count does not allow it, just trust me from the above citations from my experience, this is a garbage game that only people with low-standards and an abnormal admiration for RPG games should even bother with. It had a few moments which weren't really played up to their full potential, but even if they were, they would be far too few and far too far between to justify the passionless mistake that is this game. Risen 1 was a bit better, but not by too much. This was just desperate, stupid, rushed, sloppy, and an overall embarrassment of a product, which becomes blatantly clear when the customer really spends the hours to sink their teeth into it only to be greeted with a rancid waste of their time.

6, 2016
												After one ~15min session of the game I decided to give it another try. Game wouldn't start. I looked at google for answers and found out that people has the same problem during it's betatests. So, devs didn't fix it in few years.This is simple - I can't play a game for no reason, I can't give it any positive review.However, I can give one insight. In first Risen, we get the old Gothic-like world - fauna is really similar, with Saurians taking Orcs place. Everything looks the same - environment, characters, magic, weapons, pretty much everything. Now I get into the sequel, which looks very Pirates-Of-The-Carribean-esque. Everything looks different, starting with character, proceding with environtment, ending with weapons (no more heavy weapons? No more bows and crossbows, but with gunpowder weapons?). While it's not bad on it's own and might be fun, I really can't see it as something good after playing 1st game. It's just not the same world anymore.

4, 2013
												This game is FULL of bugs, broken quests, and all kinds of stuff.  BUT the game works, no crashes, and nothing game breaking it seems.  With all the auto saves even if some quest broke completely there is no need to start over.  That said this game is Piratey goodness!  Outside of the bugs, the game is so much fun, great environments, so much dialog that is good, if its not good skip it, , dont like a cinematic SKIP IT, you can just review what was said in the journal so for speed gaming it works too.  Most devs FORCE players to watch cut scenes or listen to endless dialog even today, its nice this game gives us an option to skip it, but why bother, what people say is good.  There is a Gnome island in this game, a trip into the afterlife, voodoo hoodoo shamans, a wizard, many exotic species of animals to meet and kill, all in one game!!!  This game is a must play since so far there is yet to be any well good pirate games on PC.  Rating  9/10  Value:  14.99

												It's buggy, the melee combat is a weak clickfest, about half of the achievements are flatout broken, and the natives rely on some borderline stereotypes.  I still whole-heartedly recommend this game.  It embraces its subject matter with glee, and allows a huge range of abilities open to your character, everything from pickpocket monkeys and rum brewing to voodoo curses and muskets.  This is just a joy to explore and see a wealth of hand-crafted goodness.

content:
23, 2012
												This game started out as a big disappointment. I almost uninstalled after the first 30 minutes, but I'm glad I stuck with it! After playing for several hours the charms begin to reveal themselves, and the game's strengths and addictive qualities really start to shine through. Its weaknesses are fairly obvious from the beggining, and include poor graphics in some areas, particularly with NPC models. Other weaknesses include poor scripting, player-character immersion, and a general feeling of frustration due to unpolished content. There were a lot of great ideas not fully exploited. However, the RPG adventure with the pirate theme, with ships, crew, treasures, and some particularly hilarious gnomes, made this a worthy investment. After almost 62 hours of gameplay, I have not a single regret. Risen 2 is difficult to score. I'd have to give it a 7 out of 10 overall, but there are times during the game when you'll swear it deserves a 9. I'd recommend it to any RPG fan.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
6, 2013
												Starting out a journey as an undercover pirate and finishing it with your own crew and a ship, you can expect a lot of fun from this game. It doesn't go any near the grand epicness of games like The Witcher 2 or the like of it, but it certainly has a lot to offer. Be prepared for a regular Piranha Bytes like gameplay, as all that makes the game different from Gothic is the story and the setting. The game is definitely good looking and has some nice tunes to play to, but overall you wouldn't say it's an AAA quality product. In general, it feels like an indie RPG, different from other games (except PB games) and definitely with some fresh ideas and a good plot. Worth a shot, get it now if you simply like a good adventure or wait for a Steam sale if you have a better game in mind. If you spend a good deal exploring and get all the DLC, you'll find yourself in a 30 - 35 hour game with amazing atmosphere and sense of exploration.

content:
1, 2014
												I really like the way that this game works.  You start out with a game that looks bad, and you can not really do anything, then just by playing, and making choices, you will find that there is actually a lot that you can do, and your skills just keep getting better.  You actually have to figure out how to use the new skills that you are taught by the various NPC's all on your own. There is no hand holding, though you do get a lot of clues if you pay attention to the NPC's, and what they tell you.The first 6 hours or so you will be completely confused, and afraid to do much, but that will change considerably as you reach hour 8, then by 11 hours in you are able to really see the forest, and the trees.I am 22 hours in, and having a lot of fun.  This is no AC4, but AC4 looks to have taken a lot from this game. The depth of the characters, and the story will keep me playing to the end.  Now I really want Risen 3, with this sort of open play-style, and improved graphics, and power 3 can only be incredible.Jesse of www.Jesse.ca

It embraces its subject matter with glee, and allows a huge range of abilities open to your character, everything from pickpocket monkeys and rum brewing to voodoo curses and muskets.  This is just a joy to explore and see a wealth of hand-crafted goodness.

												I understand why this game has mixed reviews.CONS:1.  First the worst part of the game: the combat mechanics.  Clunky and frustrating, but can be 'finessed' by levelling up your Blades skill and getting used to the controls.  (It's also much easier once you can bring a companion.)2.  Boring Game Design:  I understand why game designers want to prevent grinding, but gameplay and atmosphere suffer when there's little to no monster regeneration.  Clear a map and all of a sudden this once dangerous jungle is now...  empty.  Six days later- still empty.  Better game design would've been to regenerate the creatures and lower the amount of experience you get.3.  Unbalanced Game Design: My favorite part of a RPG is getting your ♥♥♥ kicked at the beginning and slowly becoming stronger- better skills, better armor, etc.  The beginning was hard, exploration was fun, keeping track of locked chests to return to unlock later- great, but pretty early on, I acquired 90% of the equipment that I used for the entire game.  Boring.  Chest after chest and nothing good.  Tons of gold, jade, gems- but you didn't need it.  No skills that you were dying to upgrade.  No equipment to save up for.  Nobody wants to finish a RPG with 10,000,000,000 gold and 99 health potions, but it happens.  There should always be a struggle- especially towards the end.4.  Damn you, DLC!!!  DLC should be extras- you shouldn't feel like the designers removed part of the full game to make a few extra bucks.  You have all these empty crew slots and it wasn't until the very end that I realized that those slots are for DLC characters.  I'm going towards the big battle, but I still have empty crew slots, so I get excited that there's going to be more.  There's not.  Final battle is stupid easy.  Additional crew isn't necessary.  Better equipment isn't necessary.  Higher skill levels definitely not necessary.  Game designers- It's poor game design to put a hint in the game to visit a location that's only available through DLC.  Eff you.PROS:that satisfying THUD when you kill a turkeyTrained MonkeysAttack ParrotsVoodoo DollsTreasure MapsAtmosphereGeneral ExplorationLocked ChestsBrew Alcohol / PotionsForge WeaponsBuild GunsCreate Amulets & SceptresFoul mouthed gnomes- F**K YES!It was fun while it lasted- my disappointment only set in towards the end of the game.

Let's change the movement mechanics!" and was annoyed and could only turn the camera with the mouse which frustrated me for some odd reason and upon opening a chest, I was introduced to a different screen which confused me more and wondered was wrong with the way it was before. Sure these problems seem stupid but  is a bit irritating since I got used to the first Risen and expected some similarities in the way mechanics work.So annoyed by the difference in moving and jumping I actually quit out of the sheer annoyance of "Is it really a better game if they changed things to make it more difficult if you have played the first game?" To be honest I liked how jumping while running actually made you go farther, but that is not the case in this game. Being a fan of the last game, I do NOT like even some of the simplest changes that have been made because I just like little conveniences of the last game, which this doesn't.Oh well. (TL;DR)

												Only for true fans (sadly)Pro:- Pirate-themed Gothic / Risen!- Great jokes / main character as usual- Atmosphere- VoodooCon:- MANY(!) bugs, horribly programmed.- expect many crashes (the game normally works for me after the 4th crash after 1-5 minutes ingame PER DAY)- Publisher does not fix all those mistakes even though they are known for years- "solutions" like "reduce graphics to a great extend", "uninstall graphic cards features(!)" etc.- "solutions" let the game run, but it's still unstable.- quicksaves, autosaves etc. won't overwrite themselves; you'll end with hundrets of saves if you don't delete them manually (watch out that you do not accidently delete your latest savegame; I did so once and the game crashed of course while deleting old saves before I was able to make a fresh save; I lost hours of gameplay.)- Game gets slower and slower if you play longer (feels like 4 fps in the end - on modern PC's)- Do not expect any more fixes - ever.Neutral: (spoiler and opinion)- I don't like the combat system, but the companions help a lot.- I met about 12 hookers but only scored at the Librarian so far ;)- Learning lockpicking is essential, but the first islands got many medium-extreme chests (skill 30-90), but Antigua's wilderness area got many easy ones (skill 20)?- The game feels very linear first, but don't worry: later you can visit the "old" islands again.This game feels like a Pirate-themed Gothic 3; sadly, there are so many bugs and crashes that it *really* annoys the gameplay. Only the atmosphere (I simply love pirates, voodoo and the old gothic games etc.) will let me try to finish this game.--> Do you remember the first versions of Gothic 3 where at least 20% of the skills did not work at all (like all poison perks) and there were at least 30 reasons why the game crashed or had heavy graphic issues? They patched it (especially with those fanpatches), but do not expect *any* of those fixes for Risen 2.I'll change this rewiew to a "thumbs up" as soon as the game gets some fixes so it would run stable, but let's be honest: it's more likely to accidently stumble (in real life) into a time-annomaly to find yourself in the golden age of piracy ;)--> get this game in a sale if you want to finish the whole Risen storyline and love pirates, but expect *many* frustrating moments while doing so.--> do not buy this game otherwise; try Assassins Creed 4 Black Flag instead if you want a much better open world Pirate game or Gothic 1-3 instead (yes, I'd rather play Gothic 1 than Risen 2 if it wasn't for the pirates (and voodoo); Gothic 2+3 feel much more satisfying than this one; but I finished each of them several times and want to see the Risen 2 ending).

0, 2013
												Avast ye, matey! Give up yer plunder, lest we send ye down tae Davey Jones' lockerrr!Over the top pirate language like this contributes to our overall "enough with the pirates already"-attitude and it speaks for Risen 2 to refrain from exactly that. Yes, Risen 2 is essentially about pirates in a Caribbean-like setting, fighting each other with sabres and pistols and sailing the oceans in pursuit of treasure. All of this is more of a setpiece, though, as this game is a sequel to the first Risen, which only featured a handful of pirate-like characters. Being a sequel, Risen 2 does what Risen 1 did, only better. The combat is more refined (though still wonky, more later), the story was expanded and everything looks even better. Considering this is a low-medium budget title, the graphics are gorgeous, with the exception of character models.Risen 2 is a classic PC RPG, third person and with a healthy balance between action-oriented combat and interactive narratives. Depending on how interested in the story and sidequests you are, you will spend most of your time talking to people. The English VO is, unliike the early Gothics or even Risen 1, not as terrible as it used to be, although you will run into various people with the same voice over and over again. Combat is definitely not one of Risen 2's big strengths, as it ofttimes feels unresponsive and flatout unfair, when fighting against multiple opponents. It turns out some of the fighting-styles just are not very good in this game. My tip would be to stay away from a purely melee-focused build and invest in firearms, throwing weapons or magic. Also be sure to have a companion with you whenever possible, as they make everything a lot easier. Risen 2 does enough to keep you interested, offering a plethora of different skills, including some for forging swords and even firearms, to alchemy and Voodoo, this game's magic. Speaking of Voodoo, at one point in the game you'll have to decide whether to ally with the Inquisition (sort of like colonial marines) or the natives (your standard, dark-skinned indigenous people), which will affect how the rest of your game is played. Not only will you have access to their specific areas of expertise (natives use throwing spears and magic while the Inquisition favours muskets), you will also have different possibilities to tackle some of the quests, with Voodoo clearly being the more entertaining choice as it lets you take over certain characters for a while and speak with their voice. My complete playthrough of Risen 2 took me 24 hours in total, with a good amount of exploration and sidequesting, though I did skip a lot of the dialogue (your classic "I'm much faster just reading the subtitles than listening to you"-behaviour). What you can expect of the game is an adventurous experience of once reknown RPG-artisans PiranhaBytes, intendet to be a treat for those who loved Gothic I and II and were sorely disappointed by Gothic III. If you would like to relive some of those days, but do not want to go all the way back to Gothic, I would definitely recommend giving Risen a chance.

, 2015
												I really liked Risen 2.  When it was over, I wished there was more. I really liked the story, I liked the characters, and I loved the locations. Risen 1, on the other hand, was an ok time waster, but by the time it was over, I was really ready for it to be over (because I had gotten bored).  Get both if you can, but if I had to chose I would definitely recommend this game. Risen 2 is set in gorgeous island jungles that feel a lot more open they actually are, and there are a good number of islands you get to visit.  Early on you are allowed to fast travel so you don't have to keep running the same paths over and over - and OVER - again (like in Risen 1).  The pirate aspect of the game is only to get a ship for transport between locations and to hold your crew (you can chose between most of them for traveling/fighting companions when you leave the ship)...there are no sea battles.  It would have been great if there were, but they had no part of the story.There's a crafting system is based on the skills you decide to acquire and the recipes you find/pay for...you gather the materials as you play.  Money is really hard to come by in the beginning, frustratingly so...and every skill has to be bought.   I am not really thrilled with the skill system, most of the skills aren't as useful as they should be.  A number of them are really useful once or twice, but then you never need them again.  Others you want to max out as soon as possible...but you don't know which till the end of the game.  (or unless you look at a game guide)I am also not thrilled with the fighting system.  I ended up hack and slashing despite the fact I was also supposed to be able to parry and riposte...I don't know for sure that I ever managed to...I can't swear that they actually work.  I had the same problem in Risen 1 though.  I was never sure if I was doing it right, so quit trying after a while.  Have lots potions and grog on hand.  I lived and my opponents died though, so in the end it worked out.The game has faults but none that ever made me yell at the screen.  It was quite an enjoyable ride while it lasted.

												Piranna Bytes as a company is one that I have always made a point of following.  Enjoyable, but tending to be overly buggy games at times.  Through their Gothic series, and then the split with their publisher then to the Risen series, they have consistently delivered a good product.  If their style of games is one that you like, then you will likely enjoy this game.As a sequel to the first Risen, the game presents itself in a much more fleshed out world than before.  Adopting the pirate theme that it seems most every game lately dips its toes into, you'll find yourself travelling from island to island while following the main quest line.  The combat is a bit shakey, the questing a bit wonky at times, and you can almost forget about getting every achievement the game offers (kill 20 ambient creatures?  Pretty sure I did that multiple times over) but in the end, the game was very enjoyable and well worth my time.One of the issues I tended to have with this is I would start the game, and get distracted, then come back to it and restart.  Did that multiple times.  But, this time I finally stuck with it and finished.  Overall, I was very happy with the experience, and hope that Risen 3, Titan Lords, will bring many of the same elements with improvements.

												This is the only open world western-style-pirate-rpg that exists. It is a recommended buy for that thing alone. I compare it with Bound by Flame or Bioware rpg-s. The swashbuckling pirate atmosphere is pulled off perfectly with jungle settings, voodoo magic and mysterious forgotten temples full of monsters and traps. Which is the reason why you should buy this game - because of the atmosphere! You are free to roam the seas and interact with characters and on board your own ship and embark on sidequests or follow the be-the hero-and-save-the-world type main quest. The combat is bad, not terrible and takes a bit of patience to get around to, but this is offset by the perfect pirate atmosphere and pirete dialogue. I raised only social and non-combat skills through maybe 75% of the game and I had no problem getting through the rest. Besides being social, sneaking and piratting is what this game does well, so that is what you want to focus on, not the hokum combat. It is unique - buy it!:risen2skull:

er 31, 2015
												I greatly enjoyed the first game of the series, even though it had a few nasty progess-blocking quest bugs. So I was excited to play this pirate-filled sequel. But any virtues the game might have possessed were overshadowed by my feeling uncomfortable playing it. I couldn't enjoy the roleplaying experience soon after arriving at the Sword Coast, and just put the game down. If they were going for a level of social authenticity with the rampant racism, they definitely nailed it. Unfortunately I can't enjoy a roleplaying game where the protagonists are violently racist.The first instance that really surprised me was when you meet the governor of Tacarigua, an obviously corrupt and shady character. He requests you to bring him the heads of some escaped slaves. His character is further proven as he regards them as completely sub-human when you express doubt about his goals. "Oh boy!" I thought, "I can't wait to side with these natives against this horrible governor!" But no, not an option. This side quest has only one possible outcome: murder the escaped slaves for the governor.That was just one optional side-quest though, and I was enjoying the game play and other quests well enough, so I continued on with optimism that I could still be a good guy. Until the Sword Coast.Where we encountered some natives who'd allied with Crow's men. Not an optional part of the plot. And I don't expect every colored person in this white-dominated game to be a good guy, so natives I had to attack wasn't the problem. The problem was with what Patty said. The protagonist says, "What does that mean?" in response to one of the natives speaking a foreign language. To which Patty replies, "It means first we kill the idiot that doesn't speak our language."I was shocked and disappoitned at the racism coming from a major ally NPC. I realized then that these were protagonists I wasn't going to be able to enjoy playing, and I put the game down. It's a shame, because I enjoyed many other aspects of the game. But I don't recommend it for anyone who might share racial and sociopolitical sensitivities. The protagonists are just not worth rooting for.

												Risen 2: Dark Waters is a decent Gothic-like RPG, don't get me wrong there, but it just don't live up to the quality levels of the previous Piranha Bytes. Even though the first installment of the past-Gothic franchise was not especially great, it had some great elements and in overall, it benefited mostly from the vibe of the original trilogy of games. However, this does not apply in most parts to the sequel which felt like a cheap stuffing made on a tight budget, where the pirate theme as well as pirate stereotypes did not help. Bad character animation, and relatively short single player campaign filled with rather simplistic quest design did nothing to drag the game out of the mediocre. So to keep it short - Risen 2 is a mediocre RPG, which is at parts relatively fun, but does nothing new, inventive or worthwhile. You will play it once and then forget all about it.

												Risen 2 is the sequel to Risen and, personally, I enjoy it much more than the first. The combat has improved; albeit, not by much. You are the same exact character as you were in the first game, you don't get much exposition as to what happened in the previous game so hopefully you can do as I did and finish the first Risen before playing this.This sequel to the Gothic successor is another great action RPG for fans of cult-hit games that many people seem to just dislike simply because they only care about AAA titles but seem to buy other games just to rag on them.Simply put: Risen 2 is the Pirate Action RPG that no one asked for and nobody knew that they wanted. It is a very fun game and I just love allocating my skill points, you don't get XP, you get GLORY! Little things like that, make this game well worth while and a fun experience for Action RPG fans to enjoy. If you're into games that don't look amazing or control super smoothly (IE: Splatterhouse, Venetica, BloodRayne, Way of the Samurai, The Force Unleashed, Of Orcs and Men, etc.) then this is an excellent choice.PROS:+ Great Pirate game+ Fun action RPG+ Graphics look pretty good+ Animations, though clunky, look alright+ Good soundtrack+ A lot of fun side-quests+ Improved combat+ Weapon system and equipment are good to use+ Easy to learn+ That water sure is pretty+ A good story worth telling and worth listening toCONS:- Voice acting not so great- Combat still kinda clunky- Some characters are annoying- Sometimes feels a little too linear- Frustratingly easy to die at some times- Traps can one hit kill you- Animations can be clunky- So many jagged edged- Still no swimming, curse those dangerous waters

content:
18, 2014
												***I've edited this review after completing the game. See further *** markings below.As of being halfway through Risen 2, it is my opinion that while this game does have some minor to moderate issues that affect gameplay, there's still enough meat in the game to keep me playing.Weaknesses:Graphics performance: this game has optimization issues. By no means do I have a beast machine (3rd gen i7, Intel HD Graphics 4000, 8 GB RAM), but Saints Row IV runs faster for me than this game does; I've not had a moment of smooth movement for ~15 hours of gameplay, and that's on low graphic settings. I usually don't let graphics get in the way of my gaming, but for a 2012 game, I at least expect a decent frame rate if the graphics are going to be sub-par for its era.Camera and Mouse SensitivityI'm lumping these two together because Risen 2 makes a strange relationship between these two things. First, there is NO mouse sensitivity--your only option for what is a ridiculously high default camera movement speed is to lower that, but you're not out of the woods. Mouse sensitivity is really high for menus, dialogue, and some minigames. The mouse sensitivity is particularly an awful experience when in some minigames, like the shooting range; the only option you have to try and keep your sanity is to lower the game's difficulty to slow everything but your cursor down.PerspectiveThe player's perspective throughout the game is a touch annoying at times; you can never look up, and trying to line yourself up right to notice items on the ground, on tables, or next to sleeping NPCs that will murder you if you wake them can be an unreasonably frustrating part of this game.***Combat: This game's combat system is horrible. The game clearly tries to create a complex system for swordplay, but guess what? You won't be needing it, and you won't want to use it, either. Advanced swordplay techniques can't be used on monsters, so there's more than half of the enemies in the game you don't get to use that with, but there's an even bigger reason not to use swordplay: GUNS. Guns are SO OVERPOWERED that once you start, you'll never go back. A half decent rifle and pistol ensures victory over every enemy with a hit-and-run approach. It should not be up to the player to make the game more interesting for themselves--this game fails to make combat interesting.***Bugs and glitches: And here we are, the reason I came back to edit my review. The bugs and glitches in this game are the worst I've personally experienced. I should not need to worry about a boss disappearing while still holding loot I need. I should not have to use the in-game console to grant myself said item. There are so many little things here and there that are broken that the overall gaming experience drastically declines--you are playing a broken game, and it doesn't feel good after the time this game takes to complete.Strengths:***Difficulty: Technical issues aside, this game is actually difficult--until you get access to guns. I will congratulate this game for making difficulty a strength early game, but the game doesn't adapt to the weapons you later get access to--you'll eventually dominate everything because the game does nothing to challenge you further than it does from the start.Culture and humor: The pirate culture of Risen 2 is really entertaining. While the voice acting isn't always awesome, the content of what you hear usually sticks pretty true to what we think pirates said and did. The humor is also fairly rich for a game that doesn't seem to have the best writers ever; I caught myself laughing a tad uncontrollably once or twice. I'll give the game that much.Final say:This is a game that is close to doing many things right but leaves nothing polished. My first pass at this review happened halfway through the game, and now that I've finished it, I can confidently denounce this game. If you already have it, don't waste your time, and if you don't, don't buy it.

												Tried really hard to like this game, especially after shelling out for it.. Unfortunately I can't really rate it as anythig better than somewhere between.. Mediocre and Decent. The controls are awkard and unresponsive and often quite frustrating. Combat is, at best, wonky. I frequently found attacks not really responding well, in addition to being unable to block/dodge effectively. There were also quite a few bugs I ran into while playing even earlier on, and the design seems a bit off. For example, spending a great deal of experience (glory) and guild to train lockpicking on the first part of the game, only to find three out of four locked chests required 90 skill, whereas I had only 20 (and the fourth chest still took 30, so). The voice acting is so so, not unbearable at least. Altogether, for the price, I cannot recommend this game. Biggest complaint is awkward and unresponsive controls, by far.

												This is a pretty daft game, but it has heart and is a good RPG if you don't mind the stupid somewhat childish sense of humour.  Been playing for 26 hours or so, and there's a bit of diversity, plenty of exploration, but, boy does it take time to get skilled up.  I think i paid 14 quid for this, and I'm happy with my purchase. Don't expect an elder scrolls romp, or a assassins creed game though. It's more like Two Worlds Two. Good game, loads to do, loads to explore and steal. Decent loot, and I don't mind the combat system, though I've heard people slag it off. It's basic but it gets the job done. There's a god mode too if you need it. The hero is a bit of a knob head, so you'll most likely skip all the cutscenes to save punching a hole through your screen. I'd recommend this game even so.

												Starting out a journey as an undercover pirate and finishing it with your own crew and a ship, you can expect a lot of fun from this game. It doesn't go any near the grand epicness of games like The Witcher 2 or the like of it, but it certainly has a lot to offer. Be prepared for a regular Piranha Bytes like gameplay, as all that makes the game different from Gothic is the story and the setting. The game is definitely good looking and has some nice tunes to play to, but overall you wouldn't say it's an AAA quality product. In general, it feels like an indie RPG, different from other games (except PB games) and definitely with some fresh ideas and a good plot. Worth a shot, get it now if you simply like a good adventure or wait for a Steam sale if you have a better game in mind. If you spend a good deal exploring and get all the DLC, you'll find yourself in a 30 - 35 hour game with amazing atmosphere and sense of exploration.

content:
23, 2012
												This game started out as a big disappointment. I almost uninstalled after the first 30 minutes, but I'm glad I stuck with it! After playing for several hours the charms begin to reveal themselves, and the game's strengths and addictive qualities really start to shine through. Its weaknesses are fairly obvious from the beggining, and include poor graphics in some areas, particularly with NPC models. Other weaknesses include poor scripting, player-character immersion, and a general feeling of frustration due to unpolished content. There were a lot of great ideas not fully exploited. However, the RPG adventure with the pirate theme, with ships, crew, treasures, and some particularly hilarious gnomes, made this a worthy investment. After almost 62 hours of gameplay, I have not a single regret. Risen 2 is difficult to score. I'd have to give it a 7 out of 10 overall, but there are times during the game when you'll swear it deserves a 9. I'd recommend it to any RPG fan.

												I recommend this title to all the people who do not hate themselves enough in their daily lives.Really! You need to be taken down to reality again? You struggle with the feeling of too much self-worth? You suffer from the nausea of being too happy with how things are going? You haven't thought of cutting of your nose for two days because life's just so great? This is it! The solution for all your ailments.That is to say the game itself is actually not that bad. If you liked the old Gothic games back in the day then let me tell you, the atmosphere is just the same. The problem is, Risen 2 is just horribly executed. And it has innumerable details that just make the pus in my abscesses boil with uncontrolled rage. It begins with no slots for auto- and quicksaves, which starts you of with 424 savegames more and three gigabytes hdd space less after 51 minutes, crosses over to an utterly ♥♥♥♥ed up combat system and leaves you with laughable animations. Now, I don't need no fancy graphics to enjoy me a nice slice of videogame since I'm blind anyway and only play by sound but if the running of your mighty pirate looks like he either has to ♥♥♥♥ like a hipster with an exploded bladder or has a wooden lower leg that has been glued to his knee with the pus from my abscesses than you cannot help but stare at it. All. The. ♥♥♥♥ing. Time.Also, it seems that some of the achievements are broken so if you're a chievo-♥♥♥♥♥ like me you get some extra ground for raging. It's a full service packet!I paid 7.50 bucks in the summer sale and that's 5 too much. I still play it though. Why? Because I felt rather good the last few days and I can't live with myself if I'm in such a state...

												Okay, so you're buttpirate and professional slacker, Kirby Cuddletongue, and your superiors basically tell you to go ♥♥♥♥ yourself and masquerade as an enemy to the state, just so they can finally have a reason to kick your ♥♥♥ for ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ in everyone's water barrels. Needless to say your love interest fights a Kraken and swims ashore after getting ship wrecked, just to meet up with you, showcasing your hardcore swaggery. Donning the legendary clothing of captain Assbeard, you take his identity and also his daughter in order to save the world from complete annihilation, while everyone else goes on about their lives as if absolutely ♥♥♥♥ing nothing happened. The game features a complete first person shooter system where you can take pot shots at flying alcohol, and the graphics engine is fully equipped with time warp technology, where vegetation smoothly phases into view from the 4th dimension.Be sure to bring your Dell Gaming Mouse and COMPAQ monitor for Tim Schafer's The Risen 2!

												It is a very enjoyable and immersive rpg with some flaws.I had a great time with it. The exploration, the atmosphere and the quests are really well done and keep you interested until the end of the game.The game has some bugs, also it's fighting system is not so good and not a hardcore rpg as the first Risen was. But if you can forgive these things, you will love Risen 2.And yes, the story is better than in Risen 1. It's not on the level of the Witcher by any means but it has it's moments.It is not a pirate simulator. You can't control your ship, trade or whatever. It is an rpg with pirate theme and Piranha nailed the pirate thing very well.It is a love or hate game so if you are not sure, try the demo first. It will give you a clear picture how Risen 2 is.For me an 8/10, but I didn't care the obvious flaws to much.

1, 2014
												I really like the way that this game works.  You start out with a game that looks bad, and you can not really do anything, then just by playing, and making choices, you will find that there is actually a lot that you can do, and your skills just keep getting better.  You actually have to figure out how to use the new skills that you are taught by the various NPC's all on your own. There is no hand holding, though you do get a lot of clues if you pay attention to the NPC's, and what they tell you.The first 6 hours or so you will be completely confused, and afraid to do much, but that will change considerably as you reach hour 8, then by 11 hours in you are able to really see the forest, and the trees.I am 22 hours in, and having a lot of fun.  This is no AC4, but AC4 looks to have taken a lot from this game. The depth of the characters, and the story will keep me playing to the end.  Now I really want Risen 3, with this sort of open play-style, and improved graphics, and power 3 can only be incredible.Jesse of www.Jesse.ca

												Much improved over Risen 1, this game continues the story line of the old Gothic series and the original Risen, now with pirates and traveling between islands. It's no seafaring game (go play Assasins Creed 4 for that) tho, it just offers more varied and larger landscapes by providing a number of different islands to travel to. Some technical improvements over the originalk Risen, but the old Gothic formula (several factions to choose from, trainers that have to be paid to learn skills, no really good side, some rather rough humor). Play if you like this type of RPG, it's great (more so than the first Risen) fun despite the somewhat anticlimatic final battle.

												The continuation of the story from the first game, Risen 2 continues largely in the same style. The story is interesting, if somewhat predictable, but you will enjoy the fighting, exploring, treasure hunts, and more. The combat is dynamic, thanks to a number of secondary weapons and skills.Be aware that the game has a few MAJOR bugs in terms of broken quests, dialogue, and skills. 												Ok, first of all, let me get my point across, the game itself isn't very good, it has interesting stuff in it but the game itself feels broken and punishingly difficult at an extreme level, especially at the start. The combat is ok but I would say it needs work because you struggle to kill anything even on the lowest difficulty (which I highly recommend you use at the start of the game if you want to play it)Let me save you guys a bit of time, don't buy the game unless it has got a decent offer for it and all DLC just so you don't feel like you've wasted money.It does have a few good points, it's voice acted quite well (for example) but it seems a bit Shakespearean and lacking immersion for my liking. I'd say it was the best (only) pirate game going when it was released but it doesn't even have the feel that you're escaping to a vast world with hundreds of hours of entertainment but instead jumping into a swimming pool full of piranhas ♥♥♥♥♥ first (which is the equivalent to a cheap sex transplant).So in conclusion, unless it's cheap I would not recommend you buy this game, purely because it isn't half as fun as you may be led to believing

												I really like the way that this game works.  You start out with a game that looks bad, and you can not really do anything, then just by playing, and making choices, you will find that there is actually a lot that you can do, and your skills just keep getting better.  You actually have to figure out how to use the new skills that you are taught by the various NPC's all on your own. There is no hand holding, though you do get a lot of clues if you pay attention to the NPC's, and what they tell you.The first 6 hours or so you will be completely confused, and afraid to do much, but that will change considerably as you reach hour 8, then by 11 hours in you are able to really see the forest, and the trees.I am 22 hours in, and having a lot of fun.  This is no AC4, but AC4 looks to have taken a lot from this game. The depth of the characters, and the story will keep me playing to the end.  Now I really want Risen 3, with this sort of open play-style, and improved graphics, and power 3 can only be incredible.Jesse of www.Jesse.ca

												  The Risen series continues on (sorta) from a series of games called "Gothic". I randomly picked up Gothic 1 ages ago randomly after a game I had went for was out of stock....and I'm glad my impulse buying got the best of me at least for this situation! I was exposed to one of the most enthralling series' of games I've yet to have played....EVER. Fond memories stem from Gothic 1, 2, and 3 alike in the manner and reminiscence of, say, Chronotrigger on SNES way back when. Risen 2 definately lives up to that series' expectations and is another good single player RPG game for any die hard RPG fan!     Germ Loc

content:
r 21, 2015
												Risen 2 is the sequel to Risen and, personally, I enjoy it much more than the first. The combat has improved; albeit, not by much. You are the same exact character as you were in the first game, you don't get much exposition as to what happened in the previous game so hopefully you can do as I did and finish the first Risen before playing this.This sequel to the Gothic successor is another great action RPG for fans of cult-hit games that many people seem to just dislike simply because they only care about AAA titles but seem to buy other games just to rag on them.Simply put: Risen 2 is the Pirate Action RPG that no one asked for and nobody knew that they wanted. It is a very fun game and I just love allocating my skill points, you don't get XP, you get GLORY! Little things like that, make this game well worth while and a fun experience for Action RPG fans to enjoy. If you're into games that don't look amazing or control super smoothly (IE: Splatterhouse, Venetica, BloodRayne, Way of the Samurai, The Force Unleashed, Of Orcs and Men, etc.) then this is an excellent choice.PROS:+ Great Pirate game+ Fun action RPG+ Graphics look pretty good+ Animations, though clunky, look alright+ Good soundtrack+ A lot of fun side-quests+ Improved combat+ Weapon system and equipment are good to use+ Easy to learn+ That water sure is pretty+ A good story worth telling and worth listening toCONS:- Voice acting not so great- Combat still kinda clunky- Some characters are annoying- Sometimes feels a little too linear- Frustratingly easy to die at some times- Traps can one hit kill you- Animations can be clunky- So many jagged edged- Still no swimming, curse those dangerous waters

content:
23, 2014
												This is one of those games where the things you don't like about it at the beginning become the things you like about it by the end.  I dont know why it has such a low score. I would give it a solid 85. You start off on your own, pathetic at combat, easily killed. It takes a long time to level up. And unlike some games where enemies scale with you... this is one of those games where enemies are what they are from the beginning. Treasure isn't randomized. That powerful sword is in the same place with every run through. I played the original Risen and I wasn't impressed with it. The world felt empty. There were no major decisions or plot twists. No NPC companions to play with game with.  I would not have recommended it to others. But Risen 2 is a great game that I will play a second time. People who appreciate a good challenging RPG will appreciate this game. It has elements that I really enjoy. For example, travelling companions with unique capabilities, personalities and good voice acting. (Eventually) a homebase where you can store NPCs you don't want to travel with you. The game reminds me a little of Knights of the old Republic in that you have a list of places you need to visit and major tasks to complete, but you don't have to do them in any particular order and there are multiple ways to accomplish many of the tasks. Things that could have been better: There was no option for controlling your companions gear other than how many health potions they had. The soundtrack was good, but short. During 40 hours, I heard the same songs repeat quite a number times.  The day night pattern was good, but the weather changes were unnatural. The game could have benefitted from more NPC romance dialogues.

content:
ber 14, 2014
												I feel like Risen 2 is Pirhana Bytes' effort to step away from the Gothic and original Risen formula. Almost everything has been redesigned from the combat system to looting and theivery. Much of it works rather well; PB did away with shields in exchange for a more advanced sword fighting system that, unlike Gothic 3's (and to some extent Risen's), actually works. Bows and crossbows have been replaced by muskets and shotguns which some people claim are overpowered but I think they're actually weaker than the late-game bows in PB's other games and are virtually useless in close combat even with a bayonett. The inclusion of off-hand weapons adds more variety to combat allowing you to fire a pistol to finish someone off, throw sand or salt in their eyes to stun them, or cast a variety of effects with voodoo scepters and dolls.Speaking of voodoo... I haven't played with it much but it doesn't seem to be that useful. It allows you to brew potions early in the game but there is no offensive magic in Risen 2 such as fireballs or lightning. It's all supplementary magic to help your melee combat. There are some fun things you can do like take over the body of another person or make everyone run away in terror as you throw spears into their backs, but it's a huge departure from Risen's magic system (there's also no mana).Theivery has become somewhat of a mini game which makes it a lot more interesting IMO. You actually have to pick locks by moving the tumblers up in different orders which I suppose is just a different visual representation of Risen 1's system. The one thing about theivery I don't like in this game is that you can only pickpocket one item from very few NPC's, you don't get to pick what that item is, and it's never something you need for a quest unless the quest specifically involves pickpocketing that person. It's a good way to get extra gold and ends up paying for itself pretty early on but it isn't useful for anything else.Another cool feature is you can train a monkey to run through smaller openings than you could get through and steal items / pull levers for you. This is a lot like Nautilus Transformation from Risen 1 but the monkey can actually interact with the environment and you have to make it come back to you to resume playing as the hero. Oh and your monkey can die. :'( You can also train a parrot to distract enemies but I haven't done that yet.Enemies in this game are much harder than in Risen or Gothic and until you get the hang of the combat system, you will die. A lot. I remember when I first started I was getting slaughtered by Claw Monkeys and now they aren't even a concern because I know how to dodge and parry better. You will eventually face 9 foot Temple Guardians and Gargoyles that can kill you in 3 or 4 hits and you have no way of blocking their attacks, though (much like Ogres in Risen but in Risen 2 you can't dodge, only tumble away, and when you stop tumbling the enemy is already facing you and advancing again. Kinda useless).I love everything PB has ever released with or without bugs and design flaws. The world is fun, there's tons of stuff to do, and with Risen 2 they've come a long way with dialogue and plot. Even the voice acting is getting closer to the level of bigger titles like The Elder Scrolls. I can't wait to see what Risen 3 will bring to the series!

Yeah it's true that you don't get to sail your ship as you would in BF but you spend far more of your time doing the other piraty activities that are sorely missin' from the AC game. Duelin', Drinkin', Diggin' up treasure, thevin', gettin' your monkey to do your thevin', chattin' up wenches, blowin' a guys 'ead off with your pistol in mid convo, gettin' your parrot to bug your enemies in combat and enjoyin' hours and hours of piraty conversations with the fine upstandin' gentlemen of the southern isles.Some have critised this game for lacking the faction choices of the first game and being more linear in it's story tellin', but you can choose which islands you travel to and in which order (once you have your ship) and there's just so much stuff to do and to be gettin' on with you'll never really notice that the story is on rails.(I will say one other critism which is the end game is buggy as sin so be aware of that before you pick up the game.)

content:
er 8, 2014
												Graphics: 7/10 (Much like Risen but with two years of advancement. Not absolutely terrible but not good. Mediocre)Audio: 2/10 (Most of the awkward pirate themed noises and dialogue make for ear-splitting death)Gameplay: 3/10 (By far the biggest downfall of the game. There is no real parry or counter as there was in the first game, you just have to roll around, shoot, and depend on your comrades for dealing most of the damage. That or roll away into the next scene which causes all enemies following you to disappear anyways.)Plot: 2/10 (What was a promising plot in Risen was reduced to wretched spawn of Risen 1 mixed with Pirates of the Carribean. I liked Patty from the first game a good bit, but I have no idea why the developers thought it was a good idea to make the game a steaming dump of pirate cliche turds. Seriously, what in the world happened? I had to read a long forum comment to make sense about the overall plot with the Titan Lords because much of the game's direction was incoherent and unexplained. Even the wiki for Risen 2 doesn't explain much. )Characters: 1/10 (I'm not sure why the nameless hero is an idiot all of the sudden, I enjoyed most of his insights in the first game. In Risen 2 he is reduced to a homophobic, racist, blathering idiot. Patty and Steelbeard have little to do with most of the game minus a few scenes, the tribal groups are boring and stereotypical. Not a redeeming character in the entire game.)Atmosphere: 2/10 (It almost approaches the atmosphere of a decent pirate game, except not really). Verdict: Avoid this game at all costs. If you've played the first one, do a bit of research on what happens with the Titan Lords in the lore if you'd like to play Risen 3, which I hear goes back to the original roots of Risen. Overall: 3.5/10

content:
4, 2014
												This is the only open world western-style-pirate-rpg that exists. It is a recommended buy for that thing alone. I compare it with Bound by Flame or Bioware rpg-s. The swashbuckling pirate atmosphere is pulled off perfectly with jungle settings, voodoo magic and mysterious forgotten temples full of monsters and traps. Which is the reason why you should buy this game - because of the atmosphere! You are free to roam the seas and interact with characters and on board your own ship and embark on sidequests or follow the be-the hero-and-save-the-world type main quest. The combat is bad, not terrible and takes a bit of patience to get around to, but this is offset by the perfect pirate atmosphere and pirete dialogue. I raised only social and non-combat skills through maybe 75% of the game and I had no problem getting through the rest. Besides being social, sneaking and piratting is what this game does well, so that is what you want to focus on, not the hokum combat. It is unique - buy it!:risen2skull:

content:
y 14, 2016
												I love the Risen games, probably because I’m primarily an Explorer, with a minor in Completionist.  In both Risen and Risen 2, you’re rewarded for exploring.  Quite often with actual loot, but in a more general sense with the same feeling you get when visiting a natural landmark or castle for the first time in real life.  I’m not saying the graphics are photorealistic (though Piranha Bytes’ use of lighting and sound does a lot to mask any deficiencies in the objects themselves), but what stands out to me is the world design.  So many game maps seem designed to fit the mission, but in Risen it feels as though a game was laid on top of a pre-existing world that follows natural laws of geology.  From the mountains and caves to the rivers and shores, the terrain feels natural instead of gamey.  I’ve played a lot of games where the design of a particular location was good enough for the memory of a specific location to stick with me -- but in other games I remember an interesting map, whereas in Risen my memory catalogues it as an interesting place.No Risen review would be complete without a mention of combat.  Yes, it’s darn tough at the beginning.  I mean really tough.  A pair of wild boars hardly considers you a danger when you first start out.  But if you are patient, make use of your companions, and admit that a low-level adventurer needs to run away sometimes, your power will grow over time to a point where only the most dreadful monsters are challenging.  The magic of this is that you actually get a sense of your character’s increasing talents.  And, unlike some games where a numeric increment is all you get when you level, in Risen you actually get new abilities as well as improving old ones.  By the time the end of the game nears, you’ll smile when you meet up with any pesky boars, and you’ll think, “Only two?”The Good:World design: terrain, light, sound, music.  The world builders are clearly familiar with geology and history.Exploration is rewarded.Actual sense of progression as your character gains experience.Wry sense of humour without being too adolescent.While the overall story isn’t terribly innovative, there were enough twists to keep it interesting.  The smaller NPC-related arcs were definitely above average.  I also found it interesting that they went for an adult rating solely based on dialogue, and not the more sensationalist paths of gore or nudity.Unlimited inventory space!  So nice not to have to micromanage bags.Treasure maps!  Who doesn’t like treasure maps?The Bad:A number of non-game-breaking bugs, like rain not appearing after loading a previous save, a companion getting stuck on a roof, or an ability not showing up as being learned in your skills display even though your character can perform that action.  NPCs with short memories: you can steal from them, defeat them in a fight, and a moment later they will still happily trade with you.  Also, some NPCs never sleep.  Really, never.Some abilities not explained well.Some instances where if you don’t do x before y, you can never do x again.  There was one NPC who was the only one who could train you in certain skills, but after you’ve reached a certain point in the story he won’t train you anymore and just talks about the final boss fight.One clue to treasure that made no sense outside the German version.[I feel I should note that my play time, which is only for a single playthrough, is a good deal longer than the minimum required to finish the game.  This is because when I visit a world that is this rich in detail, I don’t make my character run unless there is a reason he would do so in the game, and I don’t use quick travel unless there is a plot reason for it (e.g. magical crystals).  Risen 2 has very generous quick travel, but I preferred walking everywhere to soak in the lush scenery.]

content:
, 2016
												The best game of the Risen series in my opinion.If you read my other reviews, you may have noticed that I love atmospheric games. I love games with immersion and a fascinating storyline. And Risen 2 does a great job at delivering this. First of all the pirates setting of the game is great. It's good to see that the devs have gone away from the magic theme of the first game and made something more interesting (I still like Risen 1 don't get me wrong). Instead of one big island there are now several smaller ones you can head for on your own pirate ship. There also are new weapons like pistols and muskets. Furthermore you can learn voodoo magic from the tribal guys in the jungle, unearth treasures, loot dangerous ruins, drink rum and grog - just pirate things. I love it!The graphics and the graphical effects are stunning. It's not to colorful (like Risen 3), not to grey, just right. And especially the creatures look great and realistic because of high resolution sprites. The only graphical letdown are the NPCs: Many of them look alike, their eyes are a bit too glossy and stuff like that.The graphical and weather effects as well as the sound effects are doing a great job at adding to the atmosphere. Especially rain and storms are really heavy and atmospheric.The main characters are charismatic. Every crew member has their strengths and weaknesses which makes them believable. Voice acting is above average.But the combat system is crap and by far the biggest letdown of the game. It's worse than Risen 1's combat system (Risen 3's is even worse!). Ok, it's a Piranha Bytes game but still.. this is awful. But luckily there are companions in this game, so it's playable. Seriously now, it's not that bad if you get used to it. You may need some time but it's well spend, believe me.Conclusion:All Risen and Gothic games have a certain something that makes them so extremly immersive. They are all great in some way but also have severe flaws. Despite the bad combat system, I think Risen 2 is a gem. The setting is great. The atmosphere is great. The story is ok. Buy the Gold Editon! The DLCs are nice, you won't regret it.

content:
ber 13, 2016
												I have been playing this game for a while now. Well according to steam 32 hours, but i barely noticed, perhaps I do need some sleep after all. Do I recommend this? Yeah, after this you can uninstall all your other games, I don't want the story to end.If you play with guides, I find them too opinionated, you'll miss out on a lot of random fun you can have. For example, I wanted to know what Voodoo could do and all guides were shouting 'take muskets', so the pirate in me felt like doing anything but muskets. Why bother rejoining the inquisition anyway? I never sided with them in Risen 1, yet here you start as an officer in the inquisition. You are an officer who forgot how to use a sword, gun or anything else, he even needs to learn how to kick someone. Best secret agent ever. The combat system is very clunky, near dead enemies just take a step back so the autoaim takes the nearest one and the one near dead will kill you. As everyone was shouting how muskets are great in combat, I hate the combat system, so I went Voodoo. When I thought about making another save as a Protector, I fell into the lap of a Kiki once more. The fun part is that you get to command people who are rude to you to clean the privies, resign and so on. Muskets just let you shoot stuff, like that? play a shooter or move to the USA. Once you have chosen Voodoo, you forget the clunky combat. Curses, swords and dirty tricks on every hotkey. You'll never be 'stunlocked' again as it will be you who is doing all the stunning. Large groups of foes can be cursed all at once and use your sceptre wisely. "OH CRAP THIS GUY IS HUGE" *Throw voodoo doll* "En garde you big lump of meat!"I doubt I have ever had more fun with magic in a game than this.

content:
5, 2016
												Piranna Bytes as a company is one that I have always made a point of following.  Enjoyable, but tending to be overly buggy games at times.  Through their Gothic series, and then the split with their publisher then to the Risen series, they have consistently delivered a good product.  If their style of games is one that you like, then you will likely enjoy this game.As a sequel to the first Risen, the game presents itself in a much more fleshed out world than before.  Adopting the pirate theme that it seems most every game lately dips its toes into, you'll find yourself travelling from island to island while following the main quest line.  The combat is a bit shakey, the questing a bit wonky at times, and you can almost forget about getting every achievement the game offers (kill 20 ambient creatures?  Pretty sure I did that multiple times over) but in the end, the game was very enjoyable and well worth my time.One of the issues I tended to have with this is I would start the game, and get distracted, then come back to it and restart.  Did that multiple times.  But, this time I finally stuck with it and finished.  Overall, I was very happy with the experience, and hope that Risen 3, Titan Lords, will bring many of the same elements with improvements.

												This is another oddball RPG, its fun and challenging, but it has quite a few minor bugs/glitches that will make you (hopefully) shake your head and laugh. Nothing is game breaking, but you can tell that the game didn't have a huge budget. That said, it will take you about 40 hours to complete if you do all the side quests and exploration. If you like challenging combat and a rewarding level up / progression system (and lots of pirates) this one should please you. Just don't bother paying more than $10 for it and the DLC :)

content:
er 25, 2016
												A disappointing sequel to Risen, the devs tried to keep some characters from the first game to justify calling it Risen 2 but the story has little to do with what happened on the first game.Other than that the game is decent, it's much more polished than Risen but at the same time it lost some of it's charm, the world feels more claustrophobic and small compared to the huge interconnected zones on Risen and the enemy variety is not very high, nor are the enemy designs very inspired since most of them are common animals. They also removed the mages and most of the magic abilities from the first game, and pretty much the most fantasy-RPG parts of the Risen.The graphics are ok, it looks great on 4k but at lower resolutions the provided AA solution will not help much with all the blurriness on the vegetation (and there's a lot of vegetation in this game). The game still suffers from NPCs sharing faces and voice actors.I'd still recommend it, but if you wanted a improved Risen 1, you'll be let down.6/10

												Well, what a buggy and glitchy piece of ♥♥♥♥ I played?!Although I loved first part, the new "Risen" was not that bright for me, this is not the original Risen but something different with same hero and some NPCs.  Most of the ideas were not bad, dialogues were very interesting, but the hero is very weak, prices too high and there is litterly nothing to do into regions, than to just move along Pros:+ Great visual style and original athmosphere + Decent sound+ Story and storytelling+ Jokes+ Very own Parrot and a Monkey :D+ Really good but not original leveling up+ Guns are great+ Gonmes are great tooCons:- Very weak hero for more than a half of the game- Very slow game tempo, low stamina and running speed- No gold coins can be found when they are needed the most (treasure chests 60lvl with 15 gold coins in it?! Seriously!!!)- Health regeneration from plants is very slow and not effective with fast playstyle, lots of waiting to continue fight each 2 minutes- Voodoo?! Never heared of it- Most of achievements are glitchy and if you are crazy about it like me, than this game will kill your nerves (still can remember 2000 monsters killed in a single play without quitting even to the main menu).I guess this is what players call German RPG, although all the cons, I do recommend this game for RPG fans like me. Enjoy or at least try to.

												So, I bought this game quite a long time ago, and when it came to playing it, I was actually surprised at how I haven't actually chosen to play this game.  I have played part of the first game( but that was like 2 years ago) , so i do know some changes here and there whether in combat or etc.Overall, the controls are okay casualy walking around and etc ( the combat will be talked about later).  The game itself has quite a lot of places to explore as a pirate and an interesting storyline to it. Not much was missing from not finishing the first game since some of it is told to you. You get the generic characters here and there  that don't really seem interesting quite a lot in this game. However, you do get to have certain dialogue options, but half of them only progress the quests or storyline. Don't get me wrong though,  there are a lot of quests that are out there and places to explore that will keep you busy.The only probleem for me is the *combat*,    it's honestly pretty terrible and wild  ( if you are alone, which sometimes you have to be near the middle of the game).  Sometimes you can keep attacking while other fights you get instantly stunned in a combo. Each battle is pretty difficult/tedious since your only option half the time is to play the hit/gun and run tactic. You can only parry/deflect melee attacks and dodge roll in a direction. If you are attacked, your action is canceled; however, this doesn't apply to almost all your enemies.The game can be pretty slow since everything costs so much money at the start of the game, but the game overall is fun for me.  The combat is quite bad, but it's still a restrictive character "RPG" exploring game  that i can enjoy.

												Well.. So far it has taken me 2 hours to get it to load at all, and about as much time trying to make the display settings work so it doesn't start up in windowed mode with a highdef resolution.. And I've tried everything othewrs have offered concerning solutions. Currently reinstalling it, and if that doesn't help, I'll never touch it again..If this is what to expect from this game, then I wouldn't recommend it.
